 Your choice of the term "pro-abortion" says that they try to force women to have abortions (not necessarily all women but even a subset). Pro-abortion, in any reasonable understanding of the english language, would mean an advocacy for abortion itself - i.e. trying force women in certain situations to get an abortion. This is similar to being pro-death penalty, which would be support of the death penalty - i.e. trying to have the death penalty imposed by force in various situations. No choice is implied in the term pro-abortion, just as no choice is implied in the term pro-death penalty. 
 
 I do indeed use the term pro-choice because that is what is supported - i.e. the woman's CHOICE. Nobody on the pro-choice side, as far as I know, has ever advocated that any woman SHOULD get an abortion if it is not her choice. If you claim that, then support that with quotes. 
 
 The bottom line is that terms in english carry certain meanings. If you do not intend the meaning that the term implies, then don't use that term. Namely, the term "pro-abortion" is inaccurate and does not reflect reality.

 The same claim of manipulation can more validly be made that calling a single cell (zygote) a "baby" is ludicrous and clearly an attempt to sensationalize what should be thoughtful dispassionate discussion.

1. The terms are commonplace words and they existed before and outside of the abortion debate. The terms "need to exist" because they are precise terms used in science, where precision in meaning is important. And these terms do have different meaning; that is why they exist. 
 
 2. The same claim of manipulation can more validly be made that calling a single cell (zygote) a "baby" is ludicrous and clearly an attempt to sensationalize what should be thoughtful dispassionate discussion. 
 
 3. A zygote is clearly different from an infant, anatomically, physiologically and ethically. Clearly the two are stongly related to one another, however. Therefore, reasonable people can debate the differences and similarities. Labeling them the same thing is simply inaccurate and adds nothing to the debate but melodrama.

 2. Once again, when has a young woman ever referred to the zygote or the fetus in her in a conversation? No conversation regarding killing what would be a life should be dispassionate. 
 3. A world where you get to create the definitions is a dangerous place to exist. Dispassionate conversation and absence of drama concerning killing a life is considered reasonable.

2. Once again, when has a young woman ever referred to the zygote or the fetus in her in a conversation? No conversation regarding killing what would be a life should be dispassionate.

 
 Logic (which reasoned arguments should be based upon) generally require dispassionate observation. Empassioned but unreasonable arguments carry little weight. With good reason :-\
 
 

 3. A world where you get to create the definitions is a dangerous place to exist. Dispassionate conversation and absence of drama concerning killing a life is considered reasonable.

 
 Dictionary definitions are useful, but are occasionally inadequate for fine points and differences that are important to a discussion. The abortion debate is one such discussion. Ignoring the difference, for example, between an early term fetus and born child creates confusion. For the purposes of the discussion they are different and the terms should reflect this.
